item.title: 4-1 Node.js primer
item.description:
This lab goes through the basics of the Node.js platform.

Quick start

Node.js (https://nodejs.org) is a platform built on Chrome’s JavaScript runtime for easily building fast, scalable network applications. Node.js supports the same basic JavaScript programming language as web browsers. Both Node.js and Google Chrome use the V8 JavaScript engine.

First, let’s run the following program in both browser and Node. (Follow instruction to install Node.)

// p101.js

// return the largest number in an array
// assume at least 1 entry, and all entries are numbers
function largest (A) {
  var big=A[0];
  for (var i=1; i<A.length; i++) {
    if (big<A[i]) big=A[i];
  }
  return big;
}

var N = [ 3, 7, 6, 8, 2, 5 ];

console.log('The largest is %d', largest(N));

The JavaScript engine provides some common features in both Node and browsers:

  • JavaScript language features: control flow, variables, defining class, functions, regular expression, etc
  • Some global objects and functions:
    • console.log()
    • timers: setInterval(), setTimeout()
    • date: var today = new Date()
    • JSON processing: JSON.parse(), JSON.stringify()

But Node misses some features specific to the browser platform, e.g.

  • DOM tree
    • usually we don’t use jQuery’s $( ) in Node
    • and no interface and mouse or keyboard events
  • AJAX
    • but there are other objects for network operations
  • and other APIs in the Web API

Event loop in Node

Similar to JavaScript runtime in browser, Node includes an event loop that handles events. The event loop continues until all events are handled and there are no future events. Some common cases that trigger events are:

  • timer: when time is up, call a functions
  • file I/O, network I/O, etc: When some data is ready to read, or some I/O operations finish, trigger an event and call an event handler
  • some objects can generate events
  • system events, e.g. Ctrl-C interrupt

Trace the execution of the following program.

// p102.js

var N = 10; // countdown from 10
var timer;  // id of the timer

function tick() {
  if (N<=0) {
    console.log("Time's up!");
    clearInterval(timer);
  } else {
    console.log(N); N--;
  }
}

// this starts the timer
timer = setInterval(tick, 1000);

// event loop runs here ...

At any time, Node runs at most 1 event handler. If there are no pending events, the event loop blocks and wait for any future events. If Node determines that there are no more future events, it quits.

Modules

An important feature of Node is modules, which allows you to import new functionalities to the Node platform. The Node platform comes with some built-in modules (which are installed together with Node). See the online reference for a list of the built-in modules.

To use a module, import it with require(). This function returns an object that represent the module in your program. You can assign this to a variable of any convenient name.

(You can use the REPL tool Mancy for experiment in this part.)

var url = require('url');
var a = url.parse('http://example.com/path/file.js?a=2#hash1');

(You can also download modules from the Web and install in the Node platform. We’ll come to that later in this chapter.)

The following example demonstrates how to use another built-in module os and the built-in class Date to monitor the amount of free memory. (online reference)

// p103.js
// show amount of free memory every second
var os = require('os');

function tick() {
  var now = new Date();
  var time = now.toTimeString().substring(0,8);
  var fm = os.freemem() / 1024;
  console.log(`${time} - ${fm}k`);
}

console.log('Start monitoring free memory. Ctrl-C to quit.')
setInterval(tick, 1000);

Evented I/O

Node.js has only 1 thread to run JavaScript code. If this thread blocks to wait for I/O completion, the whole Node process is blocked and cannot process other events. Consider the following example.

var fs = require('fs');
// this function blocks.
// if other event fires while Node is waiting
// for the file read operation to finish,
// the event loop CANNOT run the event handlers.
var data = fs.readFileSync('intro.txt', 'utf8' );
console.log('File content: ', data);

fs.readFileSync() and fs.writeFileSync() are two of the few synchronous I/O functions in Node. They blocks the single thread of Node while waiting for the input / output to finish.

In other platforms like Java, one usually needs to create multiple threads to handle several I/O operations at the same time (e.g. a web server handling multiple clients). Node uses evented I/O to allow more than one I/O at the same time. At the time you start an I/O operation, you also need to provide a callback function. After I/O is done, the event loop will call the callback function and pass either an error, or the result of the I/O.

var fs = require('fs');

fs.readFile('intro.txt', 'utf8', (err, data)=>{
  // if there is error, handle it, or throw it to quit
  if (err) throw err;
  // no error, the I/O result is 'data'
  console.log('File content: ', data);
} );

// at this point, file read is still in progress
// ...

// event loop waits for I/O to finish

In the above example, the third parameter is the callback function. fs.readFile returns immediately without blocking. However, the I/O result is not available yet. Here is a summary of simple asynchronous file I/O operations in the module fs. Refer to the online reference of module fs for detail.

  • fs.readFile(filename, options, callback) - read content from the file
  • fs.writeFile(filename, content, options, callback) - write the given content to the file
  • fs.appendFile(filename, content, options, callback) - append the given content to the end of the file

Sequential I/O operations

Consider the following longer example. We’d like to replace the word ‘MPI’ by ‘IPM’ in the input file ‘intro.txt’. The first version uses synchronous I/O. (Notice that this is just for illustration. In most Node application, you should use asynchronous I/O to allow better performance.) In this program, while Node is waiting for I/O completion, it cannot process any other events.

// p104.js
// synchronous version of read file, process and write file.
var fs = require('fs');

var data = fs.readFileSync('intro.txt', 'utf8' );
var newdata = data.replace(/MPI/g, 'IPM');
fs.writeFileSync('change.txt', newdata, 'utf8');

The preferred method to write the same program is to use asynchronous I/O. To ensure that writeFile is done after readFile returns data, call writeFile in the callback for readFile.

// p105.js
// asynchronous version of read file, process, and write file
var fs = require('fs');

fs.readFile('intro.txt', 'utf8', (err, data)=>{
  if (err) throw err;
  // at this moment, file read is done
  var newdata = data.replace(/MPI/g, 'IPM');
  // we can start file write now
  fs.writeFile('change.txt', newdata, 'utf8', (err)=>{
    if (err) throw err;
  });
});

In general, doing some I/O operations in sequence would involve nesting callback functions. The result is sometimes known as callback hell in the Node community. You can sometimes reduce callback nesting by moving the callback to top level functions. The following rewrite of the above program demonstrates this.

// p105.js rewrite: move callback to top level functions
var fs = require('fs');

function writeDone (err) {
  if (err) throw err;
}

function readDone (err, data) {
  if (err) throw err;
  var newdata = data.replace(/MPI/g, 'IPM');
  fs.writeFile('change.txt', newdata, 'utf8', writeDone);
}

fs.readFile('intro.txt', 'utf8', readDone);

Exercise

  1. Write a program to combine two text file ‘in1.txt’ and ‘in2.txt’ to an output text file ‘out.txt’. Use asynchronous I/O functions fs.readFile() and fs.writeFile(). (solution: p106.js)

  2. Write a program to monitor the amount of available memory to a log file ‘freemem.txt’. Hints: use fs.appendFile() to append log message to the txt file.

item.title: 3-1 Quick start
item.description:
document tree and JavaScript libraries

When a web browser loads an HTML page from a web server, it converts the HTML code into a tree structured data structure known as document tree. All user interaction in the client-side of a web app is done through this DOM tree.

The Document Object Model [(online ref)][moz-dom] standard defines a programming interface to access the document tree. Each HTML element is represented by a node in the tree. DOM defines the properties, methods and events for these nodes, and the nodes are accessible to JavaScript as objects. In summary, DOM defines how JavaScript code can access and manipulate nodes in a document tree, and all dynamic effects in web pages are realized through document tree manipulation. Demo:

  • document tree as tree of elements
  • node as JavaScript objects: properties and methods

However, using DOM directly takes a lot of efforts. (DOM is complex and verbose.) Developers usually use some higher level JavaScript library to do client-side programming (e.g. Facebook React, Google AngularJS) In this chapter, we’ll use a popular library called jQuery.

A short description of the jQuery library from the official site:

jQuery is a fast, small, and feature-rich JavaScript library. It makes things like HTML document traversal and manipulation, event handling, animation, and Ajax much simpler with an easy-to-use API that works across a multitude of browsers.

First example

This example shows several features in client-side web app programming. In this app, the user enters two numbers in text input boxes, presses a button to calculate the sum, and displays the result in the web page.

<!doctype html>
<html>
<head>
  <title>First example</title>
</head>
<body>
  <p>This example adds two numbers.</p>
  <!-- define user interface with HTML -->
  <p>a: <input type="text" id="numA" /></p>
  <p>b: <input type="text" id="numB" /></p>
  <p><button type='button' id="btnAdd">Calculate!</button></p>
  <p>a+b = <span id="ans"></span></p>
  <!-- load the jQuery library -->
  <script src="jquery.js"></script>
  <script>
    // register event handler for 'click' on the button
    $('#btnAdd').on('click', e => {
      // read value in input boxes and convert to number
      var a = $('#numA').val();
      a = parseInt(a);
      var b = $('#numB').val();
      b = parseInt(b);
      // calculate sum and show answer in the <span> element
      $('#ans').html(a+b);
    });
  </script>
</body>
</html>

As the example shows, there are several common steps in the client-side web app:

  • select elements in DOM tree. jQuery provides the function $(CSS selector) to select elements with CSS selectors.
  • read content of elements. The above example uses the method $().val() to read input in text box.
  • change content of elements. The example uses the method $().html() to set the element content
  • handle events. You can register event handlers for certain event with the method .on(event, callback)

A note on loading JavaScript code

In most of our examples, we put JavaScript code near the end of the HTML document. We typically put them before the end tag </body>. This makes sure that the DOM tree is complete when the JavaScript code runs.

We use the following HTML code to load jQuery library from our local web site (same location as the HTML code). In a more complicated web app, it is better to put JavaScript libraries in their own folder. You can also load the jQuery library from one of the public CDN. Refer to these pages for detail: jQuery CDN, Google Hosted Library and cdnjs.

<script src="jquery.js"></script>

After loading the jQuery library, we can load our own code. You can save the code in a separate js file and load with a syntax similar to above. Alternatively, you can embed the code within a <script> element, as in our example.

We embed JavaScript code in many of our example for sake of simplicity. However, in production code, it is generally recommended to remove JavaScript code from HTML file and move them to external JavaScript file.

item.title: 2-1 Basic data types and control
item.description:
This lab goes through the basic data types (Number and String) and control structures of the JavaScript programming language.

Number

Two basic data types in JavaScript are Number and String. There are no separate types for integers and doubles. (You define a variable x with var x. In ES6, you can also declare variables with let x and constants with const x.)

var a = 1;
var b = 2e3;  /* 2 * (10*10*10) */
var c;  /* c is undefined */
c = a * 1.5 + b;
console.log(c);

In addition to the basic arithmetic operators (+, -, *, /, %) (ref), the Math built-in object (ref) provides some useful functions (e.g. Math.random(), Math.floor(), Math.ceil(), Math.round(), Math.pow(), Math.sqrt() and trigonometric functions.)

(Btw, the trailing semicolons of statements may be omitted if there is only 1 statement on a line.)

var r = 10
var area = Math.PI * r * r
// same as Math.PI * Math.pow(r,2)

// a number from 1,2,3,4,5 and 6
// Math.random() returns a number between 0 and 1
var dice = Math.floor(Math.random()*6)+1

var x = Math.sin(Math.PI/2)  // 1
var y = Math.sqrt(-1) // NaN

String

Strings can be delimited with single quote or double quote. Join two strings with +. Use the property .length to check number of characters in a string.

var user = "peterchan";
var domain = 'ymail.com';
var addr = user + "@" + domain;
var n = "seven".length;  // 5

String literals use backslash \ to escape character, e.g. \", \', \\ and \n.

// no need to escape, but if you may
var s1 = 'A string with "double quoted text".'
// escape the backlash character
var s2 = 'c:\\inetpub\\index.html';

String literals can also use methods defined in the String class (ref). Examples:

var text = 'Mississippi';
var p = text.indexOf('ss'); // location of 'ss'
var mesg = "All the best";
p = mesg.slice(0,3); // 'All'
p = mesg.slice(4); // 'the best'
p = mesg.slice(-4); // 'best'
p = mesg.slice(-4,-2); // 'be'

var A = "202.175.3.3".split('.');
// an array ['202', '175', '3', '3']

Conversion

User input are usually returned as string. Before calculation, use parseInt() or parseFloat() to convert the string into an integer / floating point number.

var s = "3.14";
// unexpected result of string concatenation
console.log(s+1);
var pi = parseFloat(s);
console.log(pi+1);

There are various methods to change a number into a string.

var n = 12;
var s1 = n.toString();  // "12"
var s2 = '' + n; // automatic conversion in string concatenation

A new features in ES6 is template string. Template strings support interpolation. They evaluate JavaScript expressions embedded in ${} and insert the result into the string. Notice the back ticks used to delimit a template string.

var user = "Peter";
var age = 18;
var s = `${user}'s age is ${age}`;
console.log(s);

A longer example to illustrate number-string conversion.

var s = window.prompt('Enter radius of the circle');
var r = parseFloat(s);
console.log(`Area = ${Math.PI * r * r}`);

Comparison

You can compare numbers and strings using the operators <, <=, >, >=, == and !=. Comparison results are either true or false, which are the only two values in boolean data type.

"apple" == "Apple" // false
"apple" < 'banana' // true

The first four operators may convert the data if they are of different data type. It is especially confusing if you compare numbers with strings. JavaScript converts strings into numbers before comparison. In general, it is better to do the conversion by yourself.

"1" == 1.0 // true
3 == '3.0' // true
'3' == '3.0' // false!

Some authors recommend the usage of === instead of == in comparison. The operator === does not convert values before comparison. Similarly, !== checks whether two values are not equal without automatic type conversion.

Similar to Java, you can use && and || to combine comparison tests.

Control structure

The control structure if, for and while are similar to those in Java. Please read the online reference of if…else, for, while and switch for detail.

An example of if to solve quadratic equations 

var a = 1, b = -3, c = 2;  // roots are 1 and 2
// var a = 1, b = 0, c = 1;  // roots are i and -i

var det = b * b - 4 * a * c;
var root1, root2;
if (det>=0) {
  // these two are Number
  root1 = (-b - Math.sqrt(det)) / (2*a);
  root2 = (-b + Math.sqrt(det)) / (2*a);
} else {
  // these two are String.. sorry, no complex number support
  root1 = `${-b/2/a} - ${Math.sqrt(-det)/2/a}i`;
  root2 = `${-b/2/a} + ${Math.sqrt(-det)/2/a}i`;
}
console.log(`${a} x^2 + ${b} x + ${c} = 0`);
console.log(`The roots are ${root1} and ${root2}`);

Examples on loops.

// calculate 1+2+3+...+10;
var sum = 0;
for (var k=1; k<=10; k++) {
  sum += k;
}
console.log(`The sum of 1+2+...+10 = ${sum}.`);

// calculate 1*1+2*2+...+n*n, where n*n<100;
var i = 1; var sum = 0;
while (i*i<100) {
  sum += i*i;
  i++;
}
console.log(`The sum of squares < 100 is ${sum}.`)

A note on loose typing

You might have noticed that when you define a variable with var x, you don’t need to specify a data type. A JavaScript variable is not tied to a specific data type in declaration, and can hold values of different data types.

var x = 10;
x++;  // x is a Number
x = x.toString(2);  // binary representation
console.log(x); // x is now a String

Exercise

  1. Write a program to calculate the sum of even positive numbers up to 30. (The answer should be 240)

  2. The following program asks the user a number n, and print a n by n squares to console.

    var s = window.prompt('Enter size of the square');
/* convert the input string into a number */
var n = parseInt(s);
/* build a line with n stars */
var line = '';
for (var i=0; i<n; i++) { line = line + '* '; }
/* build a square with n lines */
var sqr = '';
for (i=0; i<n; i++) { sqr = sqr + line + '\n';}
console.log(sqr);

    Modify the program to print an empty square.

*       *
*       *

item.title: 4-2 Events
item.description:
This lab goes through events and event emitters in Node.js.

Once-off anonymous events

In Node, many asynchronous I/O operations has a callback parameter. These operations generate an once-off event when the I/O completes (with data or error). The event is appended to the event queue and the event loop periodically extracts the event in the front of queue and executes the registered event handler (the callback).

You can register 1 and only 1 callback for these once-off events.

Usually, the first parameter of the callback is an error object. Since the callback is run by the event loop (and not by any other functions), throwing an error inside the callback will quit the process.

fs.readFile('in.txt', 'utf8', (error, data) => {
  if (error) throw error;
  // no error, can process the result data of the I/O operation
  // ...
})

Timer events

JavaScript timers setTimeout() and setInterval() also trigger anonymous events. setTimeout() generates an once-off event. On the other hand, setInterval() generates events repeatedly until you clear the timer by clearInterval(). The Node process does not quit when there is an active timer that may trigger events in the future. (Advanced: timer.unref() affects this.)

var n = 1;
var timer = setInterval(
  ()=>{
    console.log(`tick ${n++}`);
  },
  1000
);

Event emitters

Objects that inherit from the class EventEmitter (online reference) can also trigger events. An event emitter is similar to DOM node in browsers.

  • an object may generate several kinds of events, each identified with a name, e.g. ‘data’, ‘error’
  • you can register a event handler with obj.on(event, callback)
  • you can register more than 1 event handler for an event. When the object triggers the event, the event loop will runs the event handler one by one.

A common example of event emitters is a basic HTTP server written in Node. (See code below) When the http server receives an HTTP request from web browsers, it triggers an event request.

// p201.js
var http = require('http');
var server = http.createServer();

server.on('request', (req, resp) => {
  console.log(`request: url=${req.url}`);
  resp.writeHead(200, {'Content-Type': 'text/plain'});
  resp.write('Hello World \n');
  // you can resp.write() more ...
  resp.end();
});

server.listen(3000, () => {
  console.log('Server running at http://localhost:3000/');
});

Installing modules

Next, we use an external module to demonstrate more features of EventEmitter.

Suppose we have a large text file that we want to process line by line. We don’t want to read the text file completely into memory buffer using a call to fs.readFile(). The built-in object ReadableStream returned by fs.createReadStream can stream the file content, but we still need to detect line breaks. Fortunately, the Node.js community has ready-to-use solution for this problem, published as modules in https://www.npmjs.com/. For example, you can use the module linereader to easily read a text file line-by-line.

Before using the module, install it in command line with npm install. Put your JavaScript program in a folder, and while in that folder, run the command npm install linereader. You’ll see that the command npm installs the module in a local folder called node_modules.

After installation, you can use the module with require('linereader'). The source code of p201.js is listed below. The module exports a class, which provides a constructor to create an object that reads a given file line-by-line.

// p203.js
// read a text file line by line
var LineReader = require('linereader');

var lr = new LineReader('./intro.txt');

lr.on('error', (err) => {
  console.log(err);
  lr.close();
});

lr.on('line', (lineno, line) => {
  console.log(`${lineno}  ${line}`);
});

lr.on('end', () => {
  console.log("== end ==");
});

The object is an EventEmitter. It generates three kinds of events. For each line read, it generates a line event. The event handler for this event has two parameters: line number, and the line content. At file end, the object generates the end event.

The last kind of events generated by the line reader object is error. This special event reports error and demonstrates an important difference between event emitters and once-off events. The object triggers the error event when its operation hits an error. If there is no event handler registered for error, the object will throw an exception and the Node process quits.

Now, try to generate an error event by changing the file name to an non-existing file.

item.title: 3-2 Select and change
item.description:
This lab shows how to select elements in the document tree using the $() jQuery function. You may then invoke methods on the resultant collection of elements.

Select by CSS selectors

This part uses the example file p302.html.

The jQuery library provides a powerful function to select elements from the document tree using CSS selectors. This function is sometimes known as the jQuery function $(). When provided with a CSS selectors, it returns a collection of HTML elements that are matched by the CSS selector.

Some examples:

  • $('#mesg') selects the element with id = mesg
  • $('.big') selects all elements that belong to class ‘big’
  • $('a') selects all elements of type a (i.e. all hyperlinks)
  • $('a[href^="http"]') selects all <a> elements with ‘href’ attribute that starts with “http”
  • $('img[alt="tiger"]') selects all <img> elements with ‘alt’ attribute that equals to “tiger”
  • $('img[src$="png"]') selects all <img> elements with ‘src’ attribute that ends with “png”
  • $('img[src*="tiger"]') selects all <img> elements with ‘src’ attribute that contains “tiger”

Change content and attributes

The result of $(selector) is a JavaScript object with many built-in methods. This is often called a jQuery collection. You typically use the methods to manipulate the HTML elements in a collection. The following retrieve or change the content of the selected elements.

  • $(selector).html() returns the HTML content of the first element in the collection
  • $(selector).html(value) sets the content of all the elements in the collection
  • $(selector).text() concatenates and returns the text content of all the elements in the collection
  • $(selector).text(value) sets the content of all the elements in the collection, and escapes the value with HTML entities, if required.

To access the attributes (e.g. src of <img>), use the following:

  • $(selector).attr(attrName) retrieves the attribute value of the named attribute of the first element in the collection
  • $(selector).attr(attrName, value) sets the attribute value of the named attribute of all elements in the collection

Exercise

Write a JavaScript program to display the Chinese birth sign for a given year birth. Start your work with p303.html. Refer to sample answer for a sample run.

To make the problem simpler, assume that the birth sign for a whole year is the same. For example, the birth sign for the year 2008 is rat. (In case you don’t know what birth sign is, please try this web site.)

Select by structure

When the HTML elements you want to select are embedded in other elements, you can use descendant selector, child selector and pseudo-class like :nth-child(n). Test the following collection in the example file p304.html.

  • $('table#marks td.fail') selects some table cells <td> inside a <table> with id = ‘marks’
  • $('ol > li:first-child') selects the first child of <ol>
  • $('ol li:first-child') selects all <li> that is itself a first child. The element must be inside <ol>

If you want to do your own processing on the elements in a jQuery collection, iterate the collection with a for .. of loop. Notice that each element retrieved by for .. of loop is a DOM element object. To use jQuery methods, convert the object into a jQuery collection with $(). Test the following in p304.html.

// this example adds 1 mark to exam of everybody!
// first, select all cells in the table body
var $cells = $('table#marks tbody td:nth-child(3)');
// for each HTML element in the jQuery collection ...
for (var c of $cells) {
  // use $() to make the DOM node into a jQuery collection
  // then, we can use .text() to read content
  var mark = $(c).text();
  mark = parseInt(mark);
  $(c).text(mark+1);
}

You can also use the $().each() method (see online reference).

// same effect as above, rewritten using $().each()
// first, select all cells in the table body
var $cells = $('table#marks tbody td:nth-child(3)');
// for each HTML element in the jQuery collection ...
$cells.each( (idx, c) => {
  // use $() to make the DOM node into a jQuery collection
  // then, we can use .text() to read content
  var mark = $(c).text();
  mark = parseInt(mark);
  $(c).text(mark+1);
});

Sometimes, you want to search for elements under a subtree of the DOM tree. You can use $().find(selector) to search for elements under the current matched set. For example, $('div#a').find('img') will return all <img> that are inside the <div> with id = a. Notice that $('div#a').find('img') gives the same jQuery collection as $('div#a img').

  • $().find(selector) selects descendants under each element in the jQuery collection. The descendants must match the selector, if specified.
  • $().children(selector) selects direct children under each element in the jQuery collection. The children must match the selector, if specified.
  • Similarly, you can find the parents $().parent() or siblings $().next(), $().prev(), $().siblings() of elements in a jQuery collection. See online reference for detail.

Consider this example. We want to calculate the final mark for the students in table#marks. Final mark = 40% x test mark + 60% x exam mark. Run this example in p304.html.

// for each row in the table body
for (var row of $('#marks tbody tr')) {
  // get the test mark from the 2nd cell
  var testmark = $(row).find('td:nth-child(2)').text();
  testmark = parseFloat(testmark);
  // get the exam mark from the 3rd cell
  var exammark = $(row).find('td:nth-child(3)').text();
  exammark = parseFloat(exammark);
  // calculate final mark and show it in the 4th cell
  var final = testmark * 0.4 + exammark * 0.6;
  $(row).find('td:nth-child(4)').text(Math.round(final));  
}

Select by position

You can select elements in a jQuery collection by position.

  • $(selector).eq(n) selects a single element at position n from the jQuery collection. n starts from 0
  • $(selector).length returns the number of elements
  • $(selector).slice(m,n) selects a range of elements

Exercise

  1. Add JavaScript code to p305.html to fill in the numbers in the multiplication table table#multitable when the user clicks the button below the table. You can refer to the output of the sample answer. However, before attempting to solve the questions, don’t read the source code of the answer.

  2. There is a tic tac toe game board in the file p306.html. Write a function show(stones) to set the game board according to the parameter, which is an array of 9 elements. An element of 0 corresponds to a circle, an element of 1 corresponds to a cross, and an element of 9 corresponds to an empty cell. Refer to the sample answer for a sample run.

Change CSS styles

There are two ways to change the CSS styles of elements. The first method is to add inline style with $().css(). Try the examples in p307.html.

  • $(selector).css(property, value) sets the CSS property to the specified value for all elements in the collection

When you need to set many CSS properties, a more organized method is to write the style change as style rules in CSS style sheet. Assign the style rules to a class, and add the class to the element in runtime. This approach also makes it easy to ‘undo’ the style change by removing the class from the element. Try the examples in p308.html.

  • $(selector).addClass(className) adds the specified class to the elements in the collection
  • $(selector).removeClass(className) removes the specified class from the elements in the collection

Next, define a style rule for the table content and apply the rule to the table element in JavaScript. You may use the following sample. When you’re done, your answer should look like this.

.mystyle tr:nth-child(even) {
  background-color: rgba(50,90,200,0.9);
}
.mystyle tbody td:nth-child(1) { font-weight: bold; }
.mystyle td:nth-child(2) { width: 100px; }
.mystyle td { border: none !important; }

$('table#z').addClass('mystyle')

Exercise

Add JavaScript code to p309.html to show student’s name and mark. Complete the function show() according to the comment. You can refer to the output of the sample answer.

function show(name, mark) {
  // display the name in span#name
  // display the mark in span#mark
  // set the width of div#bar to the 2 * mark pixel
  // set its color to
  //    'red' if mark<50,
  //    'yellow' if it is between 50 and 80, and
  //    'green' if it is over 80.
  // your work ...
}

item.title: 2-2 Arrays and functions
item.description:
This lab goes through the basics of the JavaScript arrays and functions.

Array

An array keeps values in a sequence. Arrays can change size in run-time. You retrieve an element from an array by position. Use the operator [] to locate an element at the given index.

var a = [ 1, 3, 5, 7, 9 ];
console.log(`The second odd number is ${a[1]}.`);

var empty = [ ];  // empty array
empty[1] // undefined

The length property refers to the number of elements inside the array. A common method to iterate an array is to use for loop. You can read and write elements inside the loop using [ ].

var p = [ 2, 3, 5, 7, 11 ] ;  // small primes
for (var i=0; i<p.length; i++) {
  console.log(p[i]);
}

ES6 has a new control structure for of to iterate arrays and other iterable objects. You can use it to read the entries of an array one by one. This control structure is convenient when you only need to access the content of an array, but not the position.

var p = [ 2, 3, 5, 7, 11 ] ;  // small primes
for (var x of p) {
  console.log(x);
}

In case you need read-only access to the entries and their position, use the method .entries() of Array. The method is an iterable list of tuples [index, value].

var num = [ 'zero', 'um', 'dois', 'tres' ];
for (var [idx, s] of num.entries()) {
  console.log(`In Portuguese, ${s} means ${idx}.`)
}

Basic array methods

Arrays are objects in JavaScript and have some built-in methods. See online reference for a list of all methods. The following shows some common methods.

var A = [2,4];
A.push(6)  // A becomes [2,4,6]
A.pop(); // returns 6. A becomes [2,4]
A.unshift(0); // A becomes [0,2,4]
A.shift(); // returns 0

var b = [202,175,3,3];
var s = b.join('.'); // "202.175.3.3"

Arrays are useful to keep some values in order. The following example generates prime numbers less than 200. Is also demonstrates the usage of continue and loop label to force the next iteration. Please refer to online help for the detail usage of break and continue.

var p = [2, 3, 5, 7];
// give a label to the first for loop
loop1:
for (var k=9; k<200; k+=2) {
  loop2:
  for (var n of p) {
    // if k is divisible by a prime in p, continue onto k+2
    if (k % n == 0) continue loop1;
  }
  // after the above for loop, k is verified as prime
  p.push(k);
}
console.log(p);

Functions

There are two ways to define functions: the function keyword and arrow functions. This lab covers the first. We use a function to group some statements that can be reused.

// draw a right angle triangle of height n
function draw (n) {
  var out = "";
  for (var y=0; y<n; y++) {
    var s = "";
    for (var i=0; i<n-y-1; i++) s += ". ";
    for (var i=0; i<=y; i++) s += "* ";
    out += s+"\n";
  }
  console.log(out);
}

draw(5); // call the function to draw a triangle of height 5
draw(10); // draw again

Functions can return values to the calling code with return. The return statement also ends the execution of the functions immediately.

// this function compares the two parameters a and b, and returns the bigger one
function bigger (a,b) {
  if (a>b) {
    return a;
  } else {
    return b;
  }
}
console.log('The bigger one is ', bigger(2,3));

// another way to write
function bigger2 (a,b) {
  if (a>b) { return a; }
  return b;
}

// yet another way to write
function bigger3 (a,b) { return a>b ? a : b; }

The next example defines a function that finds the largest number in an array, assuming that the array has at least 1 element.

function max (num) {
  var x = num[0]; // assume the 0th element is the largest
  // compare x with each remaining element
  for (var k=1; k<num.length; k++) {
    if (num[k]>x) x = num[k];
  }
  return x;
}

max([2,3,5,8,7,1,4,6]); // return 8

A note on variable scope

In JavaScript, variables have function scope. That means that variables defined within a function are only visible inside the function. They are sometimes called local variables. Function parameters also work like local variables. A new copy of these variables is created when the function executes, and removed when no code has access to them anymore. For simple case like the above example, the local variables are removed when the function returns.

On the other hand, variables defined outside any functions are global variables, and are visible inside any functions. It is generally recommended to use global variables as little as possible.

In addition, you can define a function inside another function. Such nesting functions create nesting variable scopes.

Exercise

  1. Write a function sum(num) to calculate the sum of elements in an array num. Use the following code to test your function.

    var x = [1,2,3,4,5];
var ans = sum(x);
console.log('Correct? ', ans==15);

  2. Write a function odd(n) to generate an array of odd numbers less than or equal to n. Test your function with the following code.

    var a = odd(1);
console.log(a); // should print [1]
console.log(odd(9)); // should print [1,3,5,7,9]
console.log(sum(odd(10*2-1))); // should print 100

  3. Write a function search(num, n) to search for an number n in the array num. Return the position of the element if it is found. If it is not found, return -1. Test your function with the following code.

    var x = [6, 8, 3, -2];
console.log(search(x, 3)); // should print 2;
console.log(search(x, 1)); // should print -1;

The sample answers are available at p201.js, p202.js and p203.js respectively.

item.title: 4-3 Web client
item.description:
This lab demonstrate how send HTTP requests using the request modules.

Module request

Node.js has a built-in module called http and https for making HTTP clients and servers. They are efficient implementation of the HTTP protocol. However, the modules are low-level and not convenient to use. Therefore, the Node community has developed several modules for writing HTTP clients and servers. This lab is about the client-side of HTTP.

A popular choice for HTTP clients is the request module. (online reference). Before using the module the first time in a project, install it with npm install request.

GET an URL

The following example fetches the current weather report from http://rss.smg.gov.mo/e_ActualWeather_rss.xml.

// p301.js
var request = require('request');

var url = 'http://rss.smg.gov.mo/e_ActualWeather_rss.xml';
request.get(url, (err, res, body) => {
  console.log('STATUS: ' + res.statusCode);
  console.log('HEADERS: ');
  console.dir(res.headers);
  console.log(body);
});

The callback for request.get takes three parameters. The first is the error object. The second is an object of class http.IncomingMessage (online reference). It represent the HTTP response message. You can use it to check HTTP status code and headers. The last parameter is the message body of the HTTP response. The next example downloads an image from IPM website and saves it.

Options object pattern

The JavaScript programming language does not support named parameters. Some APIs make use of a pattern caled options object pattern to pass named parameters to a function. For example, if you need to give more information about the HTTP request in addition to URL, you can group these information in an option object and pass it as the first parameter of reqeust.get(). Refer to online reference for all available options.

// p302.js
// - Download and save an image file from www.ipm.edu.mo

var fs = require('fs');
var request = require('request');

// options object pattern
// use a JS object to group named parameters
// encoding = null is required to get binary data
var options = {
  url: 'http://www.ipm.edu.mo/cntfiles/upload/images/common/campus/campusmap_btn_chi_un_img.jpg',
  encoding: null
};

request.get(options, (err, res, body) => {
  if (err) throw err;
  if (res.statusCode!==200) {
    console.log('HTTP status not ok. code = ', res.statusCode);
    return;
  }
  console.log('HTTP request is successful. Saving file...');
  fs.writeFile('campus.jpg', body, (err) => {
    if (err) throw err;
  });
});

POST request

In the next example, we want to download the class time table from the IPM web app at https://wapps.ipm.edu.mo/siweb/time_prog.asp. The web app uses HTTPS (instead of plain HTTP) and the POST method to send query to the server. The query data can be sent using the form property in the options object in request.post.

// p303.js
// - saves the response of a POST request to the file timetab.html

var request = require('request');
var fs = require('fs');

var form = {
  p_escl_cod: 5, /* ... */
  p_year_sem: '2015/2016-1',
  p_sp_year: 3,
  p_class_code: '31121'
};

var options = {
  url: 'https://wapps.ipm.edu.mo/siweb/time_prog.asp',
  form: form
};

request.post(options, (err, res, body) => {
  if (err) throw err;
  console.log('HTTP status: ' + res.statusCode);
  // write the HTML response body to an HTML file
  fs.writeFile('timetab.html', body, 'utf8', (err)=> {} );
});

Exercise

item.title: 3-3 Creating new content
item.description:
This lab covers how to create new content into the document tree using $() jQuery functions and methods.

Create new HTML content

You can create new HTML content by passing HTML code to the jQuery function $(htmlCode). The newly created elements are detached from the current document tree, and not displayed. To show the content, you have to attach the elements to the document tree. Run the following code in p311.html.

var p = $('<p>A new paragraph <em>created</em> by jQuery</p>');
dir(p);
// append to the document body to show this element
$('body').append(p);
// now you can see it

When you supply HTML code to jQuery function, it returns a jQuery collection, just like the collection returned when you supply a CSS selector. Therefore, you can use the jQuery methods like $().html() or $().attr() to configure the newly created elements.

var img = $('<img>').attr('src', 'ani/dragon.png');
$('body').append(img);

var link = $('<a>').html('Macao Poly').attr('href', 'http://www.ipm.edu.mo');
// this is the same as $('<a href="http://www.ipm.edu.mo">Macao Poly</a>');
$('body').append(link);

By the way, you can detach an element from the document tree with $().detach() or $().remove, and reinsert it later. To remove all content inside an element, use $(selector).empty().

// move all images to the end of the document
var img = $('img').detach();
$('body').append(img);

// make the document body empty
$('body').empty();

Insert content to document tree

There are several methods you can use to insert new / existing content into the current document tree.

  • $().append(content) - adds the content at the end of each element in the collection
  • $().prepend(content) - adds the content at the start of each element in the collection
  • $().after(content) - adds the content after each element in the collection
  • $().before(content) - adds the content before each element in the collection

If the source content is already attached to the current document, the content is removed first, and then attached at the target location. If you want to keep the source content at the original position, clone the source content before inserting with $().clone().

Now, go through the examples in p312.html.

The four insertion methods have a counterpart version that reverse the order of source and target. ($().appendTo(), $().prependTo(), $().insertBefore() and $().insertAfter()) They are useful if you want to chain other methods on the source. See online reference or more detail.

$('#rooster').after($('#tiger'))
// is the same as ...
$('#tiger').insertAfter($('#rooster'))

The following creates new rows and inserts into the table. See the demo p313.html

var $t = $('table tbody');
// clear the table body
$t.empty();
for (var k=16; k<32; k++) {
  // create a new row
  var $r = $('<tr>');
  // and append three cells to the row
  $('<td>').html(k).appendTo($r);
  $('<td>').html(k.toString(2)).appendTo($r);
  $('<td>').html(k.toString(16)).appendTo($r);
  // append the row to the table body
  $t.append($r);
}

Exercise

In this exercise, you have to populate an HTML table with JSON data in p314.html. Refer to the sample answer for the required output format.

item.title: 2-3 Objects and JSON data
item.description:
This lab covers the basics of objects (as data structure). It also covers part of JSON.

Objects

In JavaScript, an object is a collection of properties. Each property is a pair of name and value. You can access each property with the dot notation.

// define an object with 3 properties
var peter = {
  firstName: "Peter",
  lastName: "Chan",
  age: 19
};
console.log(peter.lastName)  // "Chan"
peter.age ++;
console.log(`${peter.firstName} is now ${peter.age} years old.`);

Use assignment to change value of an existing property, or add a new property.

var point = { };  // empty objects
point.x = 10; // add property
point.y = 8;
dir(point); // show structure, only avail in Chrome console

Functions can accept objects, and return objects. In the following, objects with the two properties x and y represent points on a plane.

function distance (p1, p2) {
  // the function Math.hypot() can also be used here
  var sum_sqr = Math.pow(p1.x-p2.x, 2) + Math.pow(p1.y-p2.y, 2);
  return Math.sqrt(sum_sqr);
}

function midpoint (p1, p2) {
  return {
    x: (p1.x+p2.x) / 2,
    y: (p1.y+p2.y) / 2
  }
}

var p1 = { x: 0, y: 0 }, p2 = { x: 3, y: 4 };
console.log(`Distance = ${distance(p1,p2)}`);
var mid = midpoint(p1, p2);
dir(mid);

Complicated data

A property can take another object as value. This put an object inside another object. Use nesting objects to represent a hierarchy of properties.

var flight = {
  airline: "Oceanic",
  number: 815,
  departure: {
     IATA: "SYD",
     time: "2004-09-22 14:55",
     city: "Sydney"
  },
  arrival: {
     IATA: "LAX",
     time: "2004-09-23 10:42",
     city: "Los Angeles"
  }
};

console.log(
   'This flight goes from ',
   flight.departure.city,
   ' to ',
   flight.arrival.city
);

By mixing arrays and objects, you can use JavaScript data structure to represent some complicated data. This forms the basis of the JSON data format.

In the following example, the object timetab represents the lecture timetable for 2016⁄17, semester 1. The property courses has array value, and contains an object for each course.

var timetab = {
  acadYear: "2016/17",
  semester: 1,
  courses: [
    {
      code: 'comp211', title: 'Database design', year: 2,
      lectures: [
        { dow: 2, start: 1130, end: 1300, room: 'A203' },
        { dow: 4, start: 1000, end: 1130, room: 'A318' }
      ]
    },
    {
      code: 'comp212', title: 'Programming II', year: 2,
      lectures: [
        { dow: 4, start: 1430, end: 1600, room: 'A317' },
        { dow: 3, start: 1600, end: 1730, room: 'A210' }
      ]
    },
    {
      code: 'comp214', title: 'Computer networks', year: 2,
      lectures: [
        { dow: 5, start: 1000, end: 1300, room: 'A206' }
      ]
    }
  ]
};

A note on object notation

In addition to the dot notation, you can also use array notation to access a property in objects.

var person = { name: 'Peter' };
// same as person.age = 20;
person['age'] = 20;

The array notation is necessary if you only know the property names in run-time, or the property names contains non-ASCII characters.

var cn2en = {
  '': 'spring', '': 'summer',
  '': 'autumn', '' : 'winter'
};
cn2en['']  // 'spring'
// the following has syntax error
//cn2en.

The JavaScript language also has a for .. in control structure to enumerate the properties of an object. We skip its discussion because it is tricky to use.

Exercise

Use the time table data structure above to complete this exercise. Refer to the sample answers for sample output: p204.js, p205.js and p206.js.

  1. Write a program to show the number of lectures of each course. The output should include course code, course title, and number of lectures per week.

  2. Write a program to print the content of the time table.

  3. Write a program to list the lectures on Thursday dow==4. The output should include course code, start and end time, and room.

item.title: 4-4 Routing in web app
item.description:
This lab first covers the concept of a Node app and dependency management in package.json. Next it starts the discussion on the web app framework Express.js.

Node app and package.json

In this lab, we’ll use the Express.js framework and some other modules to build web app server. As an Node application makes use of more NPM modules, it becomes difficult to install the modules manually with the command npm install module-name. Instead, you can describe the dependencies of a Node app in a JSON txt file called package.json.

A Node app contains 1 or more JavaScript file (*.js) together with modules and other assets (e.g. HTML files, images). All these file are put in a folder. A special file package.json describes the app. It defines the name and version, which identifies the app in the www.npmjs.com.

{
  "name": "comp312-examples",
  "description": "Examples for Express.js in comp312",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "private": true,
  "dependencies": {
    "express": "^4.10"
  }
}

The config file above indicates that our app depends on the ‘express’ module. It requires a version compatible with 4.10. For more detail about the version specification, refer to the online document for Semvar.

After listing all the required modules for the current app in package.json, you can install all the dependencies with the command npm install. If later, you need to add a dependency (e.g. request module), run the following command.

npm install request --save

This command installs the latest version of specified module. In addition, it updates package.json and adds the module to the dependencies. Try the command and check the change in package.json.

Express.js

Express.js (website) is a web framework to simplify development of Web applications.

  • Middleware chainable processing of requests and responses
  • Routing different request processing based on URL patterns
  • Template generate HTML output from variables

Basic structure of an express app.

var express = require('express');
// create an Express application, which will handle HTTP requests
var app = express();

// a route in the app, which handles GET request for the path '/'
app.get('/', function(req, res) {
  res.send('hello world');
});

// more routes ...

// start listening at TCP port 3000
app.listen(3000);

Routes

When a web server receives an HTTP request, it has to decide how to handle the request, and return the result as an HTTP response. Such decision usually depends on the HTTP method (either GET or POST in most cases) and the path in the URL (e.g. “/about.html”). The combination of HTTP method and the URL path is usually referred to as an endpoint of the web service.

In an Express app, we define a route to describe how to process HTTP requests at an endpoint. The general syntax is app.get(path, callback) and app.post(path, callback). The callback can take 2 or more parameters. Often, we only use the first two parameters called req and res. req refers to the incoming HTTP request, and res can be used to build the HTTP response.

// app is an Express app

app.get('/about.html', (req, res) => {
  // When the Express app receives a GET request
  // for the path '/about.html', it returns a text response
  res.send('This is a simple example of route')
});

Some web apps include parameters in the URL path. For example, the URL https://www.google.com/maps/place/Macao+Polytechnic+Institute/ refers to the place ‘Macao Polytechnic Institute’ in the web app Google Maps. You can easily extract these parameters in Express routes.

Consider the sample code below, which shows a web app to check lecture hours. When the app receives a GET request for the path ‘/lecture/comp312’, it returns a response of its lecture hours. The parameters are available in the object req.params. (The full source is app1.js).

// retrieve the lecture time
app.get('/lecture/:code', (req, res) => {
  // in a real app, we'd query a database ...
  if (req.params.code=='comp312') {
    res.send('Tue, Thu: 10:00-11:30am')
  } else if (req.params.code=='comp311') {
    // ...
  }
})

The above only describes the basics of routing in Express. Refer to the online guide for more possibilities.

The order of routes is significant! An Express app checks the routes in the order they are defined. When a route matches the HTTP methods and URL path, the Express app executes its callback function to handle the request. The callback usually returns an HTTP response with res.send() or similar methods. When a response is returned, the Express app will stop checking the remaining routes.

Making responses

You can use the res object in the route callback to build a response. (online reference) The res object has several common methods:

  • res.send(body) sends a response with the specified body. The body is usually a string, but it can also be JavaScript objects or others. The method determines the suitable MIME type.
  • res.sendFile(path) returns a file as response.
  • res.status(code) sets the HTTP response code. This function is chainable.
  • res.redirect(path) redirects to the given URL.

Check the source code of app2.js for demonstration of how to build responses with these methods.

item.title: 3-4 Handling events
item.description:
This lab covers how to handle events with event handlers using the jQuery library.

Basic event handling

The basic function to register event handler is $().on(events, handler) (online reference) This method attaches the event handler (a function) to handle the events (e.g ‘click’, ‘mousemove’) to each element in the jQuery collection. There are different ways to attach event handlers, as shown below.

$('button#btn1').on('click', function(event) {
  // do something when the button with id=btn1 is clicked
});

// rewrite using arrow function
$('button#btn1').on('click', (event) => {
  // ...
});

// shorthand notation is available for common events
// .. but this is not recommended in this course
$('button#btn1').click( (event) => {
  // ...
});

// your can also define a standalone function and later use it as event handler
function btn1_click (event) {
  // ...
}

$('button#btn1').on('click', btn1_click);

Mouse event and event object

The browser triggers several mouse-related events when the user interacts with the HTML elements using the mouse. Some common mouse events are: click, mouseenter, mouseleave and mousemove. The first parameter of an event handler is an Event object. This object includes several useful properties and methods. One of them is the property .target, which is the HTML element that triggers the event. The event type is given in the property .type. The location of the mouse cursor is given in the properties .pageX and .pageY. The following code shows how to handle common mouse events. Check a live demo at p321.html.

// this event handler handles 'click'
$('#box1').on('click', event => {
  var x = event.pageX;
  var y = event.pageY;
  console.log(`click: #box1 at (${x}, ${y})`);
});

// this event handler handles both 'mouseenter' and 'mouseleave'
$('#box1').on('mouseenter mouseleave', event => {
  var x = event.pageX;
  var y = event.pageY;
  var type = event.type;
  console.log(`${type}: #box1 at (${x}, ${y})`);
});

In some cases, we need to handle the same event type triggered at many elements. For example, in p322.html, when the user clicks at one of the 12 images, it slowly fades out (to 0.1 opacity), and then slowly fades in (back to 1.0 opacity). (This example uses the jQuery method $().fadeTo (online reference) to do the animation.) This animation is done with one event handler, which needs to find out which image is clicked via event.target. Notice that in order to apply jQuery methods, we have to wrap the DOM element event.target as a jQuery collection $(event.target).

// register the same event handler function to the 12 images
$('#zodiac img').on('click', event => {
  // use event.target to find out which image is clicked
  // do something on it, e.g. $(event.target).fadeOut();
  $(event.target).fadeTo(1000, 0.1,
    ()=>{$(event.target).fadeTo(3000, 1)});
});

Attach data to DOM elements

Although we can distinguish which element triggers an event with event.target, usually it is more convenient if we can pass some application specific information (e.g. record id) to the event handler. There are several ways to do this. The code below are extracted from a simple Tic-tac-toe example p323.html and uses the jQuery method $().data(name, value) to attach any JavaScript data to a DOM element.

<!-- the tic tac toe game board is a 3x3 table -->
<table id='tic' class='gameboard'>
  <tr><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr>
  <tr><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr>
  <tr><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr>
</table>

<script>
// attach pos=0, pos=1, .., pos=8 to the 9 table cells
for (var k=0; k<$('#tic td').length; k++) {
  $('#tic td').eq(k).data('pos', k);
}
</script>

Then in the event handler for click on the table cells #tic td, we use $(event.target).data('pos') to retrieve the position (0-8) of the clicked cell, and update the game board data structure accordingly.

var board = [9,9,9,9,9,9,9,9,9];
// player 'circle' plays first
var current = 0;

$('#tic td').on('click', (event)=>{
  // which position (0-8) is clicked?
  var pos = $(event.target).data('pos');
  // update the game board data structure
  board[pos] = current;
  // display a circle or cross
  var image = (current==0) ? 'url(circle.png)' : 'url(cross.png)';
  $(event.target).css('background-image', image);
  // change player
  current = (current==0) ? 1 : 0;
});

Pass data to event handler

Instead of attaching JavaScript data to DOM element, you can specify these JavaScript data when registering an event handler. When the event triggers, jQuery passes the specified data to the event handler as event.data.

This example (p324.html) specifies a row number while it registers an event handler for each row in an existing HTML table.

var $rows = $('#marks tbody tr');
for (var i=0; i<$rows.length; i++) {
  $rows.eq(i).on('click', { rowNum: i }, (event) => {
    var n = event.data.rowNum;
    console.log(`click row ${n}`);
  });
}

The following code snippet comes from the example (p325.html). This app populates an HTML table with some mark data for students in runtime, and attaches the event handler to a newly created table row for each student.

function populateMarkTable (marks) {
  $('#marks caption').text(`Marks for ${marks.courseCode}`);
  $('#marks tbody').empty();
  for (var k=0; k<marks.student.length; k++) {
    var stud=marks.student[k];
    // calculate course, exam and final for this student
    // ...
    var $r = $('<tr>');
    $('<td>').text(stud.name).appendTo($r);
    $('<td>').text(course).appendTo($r);
    $('<td>').text(exam).appendTo($r);
    $('<td>').text(final).appendTo($r);
    // pass a student record to the event handler
    // when the mouse is over this row
    $r.on('mouseenter', { stud: stud }, displayMarkDetail);
    $('#marks tbody').append($r);
  }
}

function displayMarkDetail (event) {
  // event.data.stud is the record of the student selected
  var stud = event.data.stud;
  var s = `The student ${stud.name} has got ${stud.hw.join(',')} in assignments, `;
  s += `${stud.test.join(',')} in tests, and ${stud.exam} in exam.`;
  $('p#detail').text(s);
}

item.title: 2-4 Callbacks and arrow functions
item.description:
Functions as first-class values

Functions in JavaScript are often described as first-class values. (In fact, functions are objects, with their own properties and methods.) This means that, in many cases, if you can do something on numbers or strings, you can also do the same on functions. In particular, you can save a function in a variable, pass a function to another function, or return a function from a function.

function add (a,b) { return a+b; }
var f = add;
f(1,2); // returns 3;
add(1,2); // same
// dir(f)

Passing a function to another function is possible. This is an example of callback, and can change the behavior of another function.

// use a function op(x,y) to combine 3 values
function combine (op, a, b, c) {
  var t = op(a,b);
  var ans = op(t,c);
  return ans;
}

// define an anonymous function, and save it in the variable 'add'
var add = function(a,b) { return a+b; }
combine(add, 6, 7, 8); // returns 21

var mul = function(a,b) { return a*b; }
combine(mul, 6, 7, 8); // returns 336

Map and filter

A common case in processing a large amount of data in arrays is to iterate the elements and perform some processing or filtering on each element.

var a = [1/2, 1/3, 1/4, 1/5, 1/6];
var b = [];
// round the numbers to 2 decimal places
for (var n of a) {
  var n2 = Math.round(n*100) / 100;
  b.push(n2);
}
// print a and b

// an array of objects, each one is a rectangle with given width and height
var c = [ { w: 4, h: 5 }, { w: 2, h: 3 } ];
var d = [];
// calculate the area of the rectangles
for (var k=0; k<c.length; k++) {
  var area = c[k].w * c[k].h;
  d.push(area);
}
// print c and d

This is a common scenario in programming. Therefore, the JavaScript Array objects provide built-in methods to iterate their content. One of the simplest is .map(), which accepts a function as parameter. The function takes 1 input, perform some processing, and returns the result. .map() collects these results into an output array.

function round2(n) { return Math.round(n*100) / 100; }

var a = [1/2, 1/3, 1/4, 1/5, 1/6];
var b = a.map(round2);

The function round2 is another example of callback function. This callback function is not called directly by your code. Instead, after definition, you pass the callback function to someone else’s code, and their code will call back your function later.

If this function is not used anywhere else, you can define it in the parameter list of .map().

var a = [1/2, 1/3, 1/4, 1/5, 1/6];
var b = a.map(function round2(n) {
   return Math.round(n*100) / 100;
});

And you can even omit the function name. This defines an anonymous function.

var a = [1/2, 1/3, 1/4, 1/5, 1/6];
var b = a.map(function(n) {
   return Math.round(n*100) / 100;
});

Another way to look at this is that a callback function can customize / modify the functionality of an existing function. For example, to calculate areas of rectangles in an array, we can write another callback function and pass it to .map().

// an array of objects, each one is a rectangle with given width and height
var c = [ { w: 4, h: 5 }, { w: 2, h: 3 } ];
var d = c.map(function (r) {
  return r.w * r.h;
});

In addition to .map(), another popular iteration function in Array is .filter().

var e = ['joy', 'sadness', 'anger', 'disgust', 'fear'];
var f = [];
for (var s of e) {
  if (s.length<5) f.push(s);
}
// print e and f

// same as the for loop above
f = e.filter(function(s) { return (s.length<5); });

Sorting

JavaScript arrays have a built-in sort method. It can sort numbers and strings, but it does not know how to sort other objects.

var a = [5, 4, 1, 2, 3];
a.sort();  // a becomes [1,2,3,4,5]
var b = ['apple', 'orange', 'banana'];
b.sort(); // b becomes ['apple', 'banana', 'orange']

var p = [
  { name: 'Peter', age: 10 }, { name: 'Mary', age: 9 },
  { name: 'John', age: 11 } ];
p.sort(); // sort by name? by age?

You can teach .sort() how to compare two objects with a callback function.

var p = [
  { name: 'Peter', age: 10 }, { name: 'Mary', age: 9 },
  { name: 'John', age: 11 } ];

// compare two persons by age
function cmp (p1, p2) {
  if (p1.age<p2.age) return -1;  // p1 should be put before p2
  if (p1.age==p2.age) return 0;  // order not important
  return 1;                      // p1 should be put after p2
}

// sort by age
p.sort(cmp);

Timer

Both browsers and Node.js support timers. Timers allow schedule of execution of a function in the future. There are two kinds of timers: one time (setTimeout()), and periodic (setInterval()). In either case, you pass the function to execute as a callback. Refer to the online reference for detail.

// say 'hello' every 3 seconds
var id = setInterval(function() { console.log('hello');}, 3000);

// cancel the timer
//clearInterval(id)

The following is a countdown example.

var n = 10;
function tick() {
  console.log('count down ', n);
  n--;
  // if not down to 0, schedule myself to run 1s later
  if (n>0) { setTimeout(tick, 1000); }
}
// tick, the first time!
tick();

Arrow functions

Anonymous functions are very common in JavaScript programming because of the asynchronous nature of client-side or server-side programming. (E.g. register a callback to handle mouse click). Therefore, ES6 defines a more concise syntax called arrow functions to define anonymous function. Usually, arrow functions are defined and passed directly to another function.

Compare the two ways to write functions below.

var f1 = (a,b) => { return a+b; };
var f2 = function (a,b) { return a+b; }

setTimeout(function() { console.log('hello');}, 2000);
setTimeout( () => { console.log('hello');}, 2000 );

Although we’ll mainly use arrow functions in the same way as functions defined with function keyword, there are in fact some technical differences. One important difference is about the this pointer. Please refer to the online reference for detail.

Array functions also provide some shorthand notation when the function body only returns an expression.

var f1 = (a,b) => a+b;  // same as below
var f2 = (a,b) => { return a+b; }

var f3 = a => a+1; // same as below
var f4 = (a) => { return a+1; }

Here are more examples to demonstrate the usage of arrow functions.

var a = [1/2, 1/3, 1/4, 1/5, 1/6];
var b = a.map(n => Math.round(n*100) / 100);

var c = [3, 5, 2, 1];
c.sort((a,b)=>b-a); // sort in descending order

var e = ['joy', 'sadness', 'anger', 'disgust', 'fear'];
f = e.filter(s => s.length<5);

Excersie

  1. Given an array var N = [ 32, 53, 42, 25, 48, 10 ], write a program to do the following. You should use callback functions. (sample answer)

    • Obtain an array of hexadecimal representation of the numbers in N. (Hints: use n.toString(16) to convert a number n to hexadecimal)
    • Obtain an array of the numbers in N between 20 and 40 inclusively
    • Count how many of the numbers in N are odd
    • Calculate the sum of the numbers in N. Try to use .reduce() in Array. (online reference)

  2. The variable comp312 is an array that contains records of student marks in the comp312 class. Each student record has three fields: name, test and exam. Write programs to do the following. Use an Array iteration method (i.e. .map(), .filter(), .reduce(), etc) at least once in each case. (sample answer)

    var comp312 = [
{ name: 'Peter', test: 80, exam: 70 },
{ name: 'John', test: 60, exam: 65 },
{ name: 'Mary', test: 90, exam: 85 },
{ name: 'Christine', test: 70, exam: 76 }
];
    • Get a list of student names in the comp312 class
    • Get a list of student record with test mark >= 75
    • Get a list of student name whose test mark is greater than exam mark
    • Assume final mark = 0.6 * test + 0.4 * exam. Make an array with records showing the final mark and name for each student.
    • Sort the list in descending order of exam mark
    • Show the student record with the highest exam mark
    • Calculate the average test mark
